body:
Hm, how does this relate to the online weighted ensemble and the hedge forecasters?
Would be good if you could look at both in detail, to avoid duplication or interface inconsistency.

@fkiraly they are definately related. 

As a start, this would essentially be the "non-online" version of the `PredictionWeightedEnsemble` from the tutorial (which is built from the online ensemble). 

Since `OnlineEnsembleForecaster` inherits from `EnsembleForecaster` a second option (but not necessarily something we'd need to do) would be to also add a weights hyperparameter to the `OnlineEnsembleForecaster` that would initialize the weights based on user input (default would be to initialize as 1 / # of forecasters like currently done). 

I'd also like to improve the documentation in this area so its a bit more accessible, but have a few questions to verify my understanding. We can work on that separately.

>I'd also like to improve the documentation in this area so its a bit more accessible, but have a few questions to verify my understanding. We can work on that separately.

Yes, indeed - especially the methodological documentation. I have to admit I'm not exactly sure which algorithms are implemented there exactly, and this needs to be clarified and improved in the docs.

Yep -- it is hard to figure that out from the documentation we have currently. I actually want take a crack at the user guide for forecasting to help make things more clear (and of course fix the docstrings as I go through that).
Hi @RNKuhns I'd like to work on this ðŸš€ It's closely related to [#1082](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1082) that I'm working on now.

issue.title: [ENH] Adding AutoEnsembleForecaster to automatically find best weights for aggregation

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
From discussion in #1139 and having weights from #1162 merged, @RNKuhns and me came up with the idea of automatically finding the best weights for the forecasters of the ensemble. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
For this we might have a separate class like an `AutoEnsembleForecaster`. We could have different algorithms/meta-models to find the best weights. One of them (and the first I would work on) is OLS. A second one I can think of would be to apply a tree-based model like `DecisionTreeRegressor` or `RandomForestRegressor` and use the feature importance score as weight. We could also have a param `regressor` for the meta-model or give it as string. For other methods to find weights, we might have to look into literature or R implementations. A a nice to have, we could always try weights like `w=[1,0,0]`, `w=[0,1,0]` and `w=[0,0,1]` in addition to the found weights to see if the ensemble is really outperforming. This could be done using a `MultiplexForecaster` and find best ensemble. We could have a param `benchmark=False` to enable this.

To apply a meta-model on the training data we have 2 options:

1. Predict insample for all forecasters (which can be an issue, e.g. ARIMA cant predict the first data points, also other models might have issues here) and use this predictions as exog data for the OLS.
2. Apply a `SingleWindowSplitter` to the train data to avoid doing insample predictions. The `cv` could be given as arg to the `AutoEnsembleForecaster` or request the train/test size. 

Solution 1:
```python
AutoEnsembleForecaster(method="ols", test_size=0.25)
```
Solution 2:
```python
AutoEnsembleForecaster(regressor=LinearRegression(), test_size=0.25)
```
For this solution, we might also have a param to know whether we need to take the coefficients or the feature importance values as weights or we handle it automatically dependent on the model type given.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
- Including this into the `EnsembleForecaster`. 
- Alternative to using a meta-model to find weights would be to do a grid search and use a `MutliplexForecaster` to find best ensemble. This would require to have a heuristic to define the grid of weights to search over. Could be computationally expensive and the user would have to provide params for the grid search (or we set them under the hood with defaults). We could add this as a further method.

issue.title: Added AutoEnsembleForecaster and refactor/doc of StackingForecaster

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Issue #1214 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Automatically finding best weights for ensemble based on a meta-model (regressor). Weights are taken from
either `regressor.coef_` for all `sklearn` linear models or from `regressor.feature_importances_` for all decision tree-based models.

I already proved in an example that `AutoEnsembleForecaster` is outperforming each single given forecaster for `load_airline` data, so we know that this ensemble approach can outperform. Code is here to see the error differences:
```python
y = load_airline()
y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y)
fh = ForecastingHorizon(y_test.index, is_relative=False)

# create ensemble
forecasters = [
    ("naive", NaiveForecaster(strategy="drift")),
    ("ets", AutoETS(auto=True, n_jobs=-1, sp=12)),
    ("arima", AutoARIMA(suppress_warnings=True)),
    ("bats", BATS(sp=12, use_trend=True)),
    ("tbats", TBATS(sp=12, use_trend=True))
]
auto = AutoEnsembleForecaster(forecasters=forecasters)
auto.fit(y_train, fh=fh)

# get prediction and weights
y_weighted = auto.predict(fh)
auto.weights_
> [0.0046995889455789235,
> 0.4021907840860222,
> 0.01191944521686898,
> 0.12701615072179243,
> 0.4541740310297374]

# create benchmark forecasters, same as given to ensemble
forecaster_1 = NaiveForecaster(strategy="drift")
forecaster_2 = AutoETS(auto=True, n_jobs=-1, sp=12)
forecaster_3 = AutoARIMA(suppress_warnings=True)
forecaster_4 = BATS(sp=12, use_trend=True)
forecaster_5 = TBATS(sp=12, use_trend=True)

y_pred_1 = forecaster_1.fit(y_train).predict(fh)
y_pred_2 = forecaster_2.fit(y_train).predict(fh)
y_pred_3 = forecaster_3.fit(y_train).predict(fh)
y_pred_4 = forecaster_4.fit(y_train).predict(fh)
y_pred_5 = forecaster_5.fit(y_train).predict(fh)

# get benchmark results
print("naive \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred_1))
print("ets \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred_2))
print("arima \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred_3))
print("bats \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred_4))
print("tbats \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred_5))
print("ens \t", mean_squared_error(y_test, y_weighted))

> naive 	 7695.698285148631
> ets 	 1153.7492147391474
> arima 	 3505.3729027077143
> bats 	 887.3656338724588
> tbats 	 801.3102613074158
> ens 	 584.1444166907737
```
Plot of the forecasts:
![output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29627036/127347954-10426913-7d71-443f-a4bc-d99b6157a4b8.png)

This PR also contains a refactor of `StackingForecaster` and docs.

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Any ideas to improve UX and performance of this class?

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [x] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
